Award.AwardTitle: NSF Convergence Accelerator Track D: Artificial Intelligence and Community Driven Wildland Fire Innovation via a WIFIRE Commons Infrastructure for Data and Model Sharing
Award.AbstractNarration: The NSF Convergence Accelerator supports use-inspired, team-based, multidisciplinary efforts that address challenges of national importance and will produce deliverables of value to society in the near future. The broader impact and potential societal benefit of this Convergence Accelerator Phase I project is to create the WIFIRE Commons, a data-driven, artificial intelligence (AI) enabled and model-based scientific approach that ultimately aims to limit and even prevent the devastating effects of wildfires by using advanced technologies to support fire mitigation, preparedness, response, and recovery. The combination of wildfire data, AI and the physics of fire behavior in the main design of WIFIRE Commons drives multidisciplinary collaboration and engagement with educators, municipal leaders, and fire managers to ensure the Commons is designed for translational use. Data and model sharing are core to the effort, as is strategic partnerships and close collaboration with the private and public sectors. The project team includes educators from Hispanic-serving institutions and advocates for increasing participation of women in the fire workforce and data science fields. In addition, WIFIRE Commons’ AI Gateway machine learning, scalable computing and interactive geospatial analysis tools will be applicable to any area that can benefit from modeling.<br/><br/>This project seeks to undertake convergence research on AI integrated wildland fire research and response, and to build a framework we call the WIFIRE Commons for using AI to enable innovative optimization of the evolving combinations of physics-based wildfire models and heterogeneous data sets used to monitor and predict wildfires in real-time. The Phase I effort will contribute toward this goal through a design-thinking approach with five streams of deliverables: 1) community convergence workshops, 2) a prototype data and model commons framework, 3) use-inspired case studies to demonstrate the proposed AI innovations, 4) prototyping of educational, outreach, and public information activities; and 5) Phase II planning. The long-term vision is to create a sustainable and open source AI-driven data and model commons to facilitate and leverage collaborations to “harness AI innovations” supporting use-inspired societal and scientific wildland fire applications. Driven by design-thinking and building upon prior research by our team members (WIFIRE, MINT, QUIC-fire), the proposed WIFIRE Commons convergence research and data and model sharing framework will enable development of novel artificial intelligence techniques and reusable models that can be utilized in many applications. This Commons infrastructure will catalog, curate and integrate data and models for AI-driven fire science, maintain open programmatic access to data in a cloud-compatible form that can be integrated into the AI process through a gateway interface, and ensure provenance of data and models over time. This AI-enabled smart data/model integration will transform the agility of science based wildland fire decision making, allowing for new kinds of models and data to be assimilated rapidly and allowing an expanding base of users to understand levels of uncertainty.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
WIFIRE Commons ultimately aims to prevent death and destruction from wildfires through AI- enabled science-based decisions for fire mitigation, preparedness, response, and recovery.  The primary outcomes of this Phase I project were to: (i) hold convergence workshops; (ii) develop the WIFIRE Commons Framework; (iii) complete convergence case studies; (iv) plan workforce development, education, training and outreach activities; and (v) engage in Phase II planning and coordination. We set out to chart a path from AI-enabled fire science to practical use in fire response and mitigation, and our convergence research approach is embodied in all our products and deliverables to date and in our plans for Phase II.
We initially envisioned the WIFIRE Commons as a space to integrate data, models and interfaces at scale and incorporate AI innovations for continuous improvement. Through use-inspired interviews and workshops, we refocused our efforts around a clear use case: BurnPro3D - a platform to reduce the risk of megafires through facilitating small, safe, and controllable fires to remove the dangerous buildup of vegetation created by a century of policies to suppress wildfires across the West. 

During these convergence workshops, our multidisciplinary team focused on deep integration across the disciplines of AI, data science, and fire science - in coordination with the fire response and fire mitigation communities to create our BurnPro3D prototype and connect it to WIFIRE Commons data and models via scientific workflows.
We focused on understanding the users who need a science- based decision and collaboration platform like BurnPro3D, aimed at increasing ?good fires? to reduce ?bad fires?. We identified four users: (i) Land Managers, planning 5-year cycles to prioritize land use and fuel treatments; (ii) Burn Bosses, planning and conducting prescribed fires in alignment with the plans of land managers; (iii) Fire Behavior Analysts, developing fire behavior information during a wildfire; and (iv) Incident Commanders, fire chiefs making decisions to manage a wildfire. The workshops and interviews that led to the use case that defined our prototype first focused on the AI requirements and techniques to advance fire science. We learned that the advances in next- generation physics-based fire models were limited by the lack of high-resolution 3D fuels datasets at the continental scale and that the lack of speed, flexibility, and interpretability of fire models limited their use in practical applications. These learnings informed our multidisciplinary team?s work to develop the WIFIRE Commons and scientific workflows that power our BurnPro3D interface. 
Our use-inspired research also helped us further define the users of the WIFIRE Commons to identify the requirements for the Commons framework and prototype the proposed technical components for extension and hardening during Phase II. For data providers, data science and AI expert users, and fire science expert users we have identified the needs in terms of user functionality, data, and AI. We worked to: (i) Catalog, index and share data and models for AI-driven fire science in a FAIR and responsible fashion; (ii) Integrate and curate data and models to create datasets that conform to accuracy, privacy, ethics, and security concerns for wider utilization of data; (iii) Develop standardized application programming interfaces; (iv) Create a scalable cloud-compatible platform for interactive data exploration, model training and sharing, and reproducibility of analytical products; (v) Build and enable development of novel AI algorithms and fire modeling research; and (vi) Track the provenance of data and models in the data pipeline from ingestion to utilization.
WIFIRE Commons develops data and AI methods across a seamless convergence integration for three interrelated deliverables: Commons Framework, Transformative Fire Science Workflows and BurnPro3D, coupled with cross cutting methods for scalable CI, interpretability and visualization. The proposed systems, services and translational pathways improve understanding of fundamental fire processes and are transferable to other regions globally where wildfires occur frequently. In addition, the WIFIRE Commons Framework will be applicable to any area that can benefit from modeling, significantly enhancing capacity of communities to use data and models towards areas including drought, ecology and economics.
Our activities in Phase I informed our planning for future EOT activities including internal ideas labs, think tank days, hackathons and datathons. We also identified the need for a Community Advisory Board (CAB) to provide broad perspectives and to structure the dissemination process from science and technology research and development to practical application. The plans for the members of the CAB include AI and scientific experts, first responders, county and federal agency representatives, and utility providers to ensure that the focus on Phase II remains use-inspired.
